00032 *=============================================================================
00033 *
00034 * WCSLIB 4.5 - C routines that implement the FITS World Coordinate System
00035 * (WCS) standard.  Refer to
00036 *
00037 *   "Representations of world coordinates in FITS",
00038 *   Greisen, E.W., & Calabretta, M.R. 2002, A&A, 395, 1061 (Paper I)
00039 *
00040 *   "Representations of celestial coordinates in FITS",
00041 *   Calabretta, M.R., & Greisen, E.W. 2002, A&A, 395, 1077 (Paper II)
00042 *
00043 *   "Representations of spectral coordinates in FITS",
00044 *   Greisen, E.W., Calabretta, M.R., Valdes, F.G., & Allen, S.L.
00045 *   2006, A&A, 446, 747 (Paper III)
00046 *
00047 * Refer to the README file provided with WCSLIB for an overview of the
00048 * library.
00049 *
00050 *
00051 * Summary of the wcs routines
00052 * ---------------------------
00053 * These routines implement the FITS World Coordinate System (WCS) standard
00054 * which defines methods to be used for computing world coordinates from image
00055 * pixel coordinates, and vice versa.  They are based on the wcsprm struct
00056 * which contains all information needed for the computations.  The struct
00057 * contains some members that must be set by the user, and others that are
00058 * maintained by these routines, somewhat like a C++ class but with no
00059 * encapsulation.
00060 *
00061 * Three routines, wcsini(), wcssub(), and wcsfree() are provided to manage the
00062 * wcsprm struct and another, wcsprt(), to prints its contents.  Refer to the
00063 * description of the wcsprm struct for an explanation of the anticipated usage
00064 * of these routines.  wcscopy(), which does a deep copy of one wcsprm struct
00065 * to another, is defined as a preprocessor macro function that invokes
00066 * wcssub().
00067 *
00068 * A setup routine, wcsset(), computes intermediate values in the wcsprm struct
00069 * from parameters in it that were supplied by the user.  The struct always
00070 * needs to be set up by wcsset() but this need not be called explicitly -
00071 * refer to the explanation of wcsprm::flag.
00072 *
00073 * wcsp2s() and wcss2p() implement the WCS world coordinate transformations.
00074 * In fact, they are high level driver routines for the WCS linear,
00075 * logarithmic, celestial, spectral and tabular transformation routines
00076 * described in lin.h, log.h, cel.h, spc.h and tab.h.
00077 *
00078 * Given either the celestial longitude or latitude plus an element of the
00079 * pixel coordinate a hybrid routine, wcsmix(), iteratively solves for the
00080 * unknown elements.
00081 *
00082 * wcssptr() translates the spectral axis in a wcsprm struct.  For example, a
00083 * 'FREQ' axis may be translated into 'ZOPT-F2W' and vice versa.
00084 *
00085 * Quadcube projections:
00086 * ---------------------
00087 *   The quadcube projections (TSC, CSC, QSC) may be represented in FITS in
00088 *   either of two ways:
00089 *
00090 *     a: The six faces may be laid out in one plane and numbered as follows:
00091 *
00092 =                                 0
00093 =
00094 =                        4  3  2  1  4  3  2
00095 =
00096 =                                 5
00097 *
00098 *        Faces 2, 3 and 4 may appear on one side or the other (or both).  The
00099 *        world-to-pixel routines map faces 2, 3 and 4 to the left but the
00100 *        pixel-to-world routines accept them on either side.
00101 *
00102 *     b: The "COBE" convention in which the six faces are stored in a
00103 *        three-dimensional structure using a CUBEFACE axis indexed from
00104 *        0 to 5 as above.
00105 *
00106 *   These routines support both methods; wcsset() determines which is being
00107 *   used by the presence or absence of a CUBEFACE axis in ctype[].  wcsp2s()
00108 *   and wcss2p() translate the CUBEFACE axis representation to the single
00109 *   plane representation understood by the lower-level WCSLIB projection
00110 *   routines.
00111 *
00112 *
00113 * wcsini() - Default constructor for the wcsprm struct
00114 * ----------------------------------------------------
00115 * wcsini() optionally allocates memory for arrays in a wcsprm struct and sets
00116 * all members of the struct to default values.  Memory is allocated for up to
00117 * NPVMAX PVi_ma keywords or NPSMAX PSi_ma keywords per WCS representation.
00118 * These may be changed via wcsnpv() and wcsnps() before wcsini() is called.
00119 *
00120 * PLEASE NOTE: every wcsprm struct should be initialized by wcsini(), possibly
00121 * repeatedly.  On the first invokation, and only the first invokation,
00122 * wcsprm::flag must be set to -1 to initialize memory management, regardless
00123 * of whether wcsini() will actually be used to allocate memory.
00124 *
00125 * Given:
00126 *   alloc     int       If true, allocate memory unconditionally for the
00127 *                       crpix, etc. arrays.
00128 *
00129 *                       If false, it is assumed that pointers to these arrays
00130 *                       have been set by the user except if they are null
00131 *                       pointers in which case memory will be allocated for
00132 *                       them regardless.  (In other words, setting alloc true
00133 *                       saves having to initalize these pointers to zero.)
00134 *
00135 *   naxis     int       The number of world coordinate axes.  This is used to
00136 *                       determine the length of the various wcsprm vectors and
00137 *                       matrices and therefore the amount of memory to
00138 *                       allocate for them.
00139 *
00140 * Given and returned:
00141 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00142 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00143 *
00144 *                       Note that, in order to initialize memory management,
00145 *                       wcsprm::flag should be set to -1 when wcs is
00146 *                       initialized for the first time (memory leaks may
00147 *                       result if it had already been initialized).
00148 *
00149 * Function return value:
00150 *             int       Status return value:
00151 *                         0: Success.
00152 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00153 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00154 *
00155 *
00156 * wcsnpv() - Memory allocation for PVi_ma
00157 * ---------------------------------------
00158 * wcsnpv() changes the value of NPVMAX (default 64).  This global variable
00159 * controls the number of PVi_ma keywords that wcsini() should allocate space
00160 * for.
00161 *
00162 * PLEASE NOTE: This function is not thread-safe.
00163 *
00164 * Given:
00165 *   n         int       Value of NPVMAX; ignored if < 0.
00166 *
00167 * Function return value:
00168 *             int       Current value of NPVMAX.
00169 *
00170 *
00171 * wcsnps() - Memory allocation for PSi_ma
00172 * ---------------------------------------
00173 * wcsnps() changes the values of NPSMAX (default 8).  This global variable
00174 * controls the number of PSi_ma keywords that wcsini() should allocate space
00175 * for.
00176 *
00177 * PLEASE NOTE: This function is not thread-safe.
00178 *
00179 * Given:
00180 *   n         int       Value of NPSMAX; ignored if < 0.
00181 *
00182 * Function return value:
00183 *             int       Current value of NPSMAX.
00184 *
00185 *
00186 * wcssub() - Subimage extraction routine for the wcsprm struct
00187 * ------------------------------------------------------------
00188 * wcssub() extracts the coordinate description for a subimage from a wcsprm
00189 * struct.  It does a deep copy, using wcsini() to allocate memory for its
00190 * arrays if required.  Only the "information to be provided" part of the
00191 * struct is extracted; a call to wcsset() is required to set up the remainder.
00192 *
00193 * The world coordinate system of the subimage must be separable in the sense
00194 * that the world coordinates at any point in the subimage must depend only on
00195 * the pixel coordinates of the axes extracted.  In practice, this means that
00196 * the PCi_ja matrix of the original image must not contain non-zero
00197 * off-diagonal terms that associate any of the subimage axes with any of the
00198 * non-subimage axes.
00199 *
00200 * Note that while the required elements of the tabprm array are extracted, the
00201 * wtbarr array is not.  (Thus it is not appropriate to call wcssub() after
00202 * wcstab() but before filling the tabprm structs - refer to wcshdr.h.)
00203 *
00204 * Given:
00205 *   alloc     int       If true, allocate memory for the crpix, etc. arrays in
00206 *                       the destination.  Otherwise, it is assumed that
00207 *                       pointers to these arrays have been set by the user
00208 *                       except if they are null pointers in which case memory
00209 *                       will be allocated for them regardless.
00210 *
00211 *   wcssrc    const struct wcsprm*
00212 *                       Struct to extract from.
00213 *
00214 * Given and returned:
00215 *   nsub      int*
00216 *   axes      int[]     Vector of length *nsub containing the image axis
00217 *                       numbers (1-relative) to extract.  Order is
00218 *                       significant; axes[0] is the axis number of the input
00219 *                       image that corresponds to the first axis in the
00220 *                       subimage, etc.
00221 *
00222 *                       nsub (the pointer) may be set to zero, and so also may
00223 *                       nsub, to indicate the number of axes in the input
00224 *                       image; the number of axes will be returned if
00225 *                       nsub != 0.  axes itself (the pointer) may be set to
00226 *                       zero to indicate the first *nsub axes in their
00227 *                       original order.
00228 *
00229 *                       Set both nsub and axes to zero to do a deep copy of
00230 *                       one wcsprm struct to another.
00231 *
00232 *                       Subimage extraction by coordinate axis type may be
00233 *                       done by setting the elements of axes[] to the
00234 *                       following special preprocessor macro values:
00235 *
00236 *                         WCSSUB_LONGITUDE: Celestial longitude.
00237 *                         WCSSUB_LATITUDE:  Celestial latitude.
00238 *                         WCSSUB_CUBEFACE:  Quadcube CUBEFACE axis.
00239 *                         WCSSUB_SPECTRAL:  Spectral axis.
00240 *                         WCSSUB_STOKES:    Stokes axis.
00241 *
00242 *                       Refer to the notes (below) for further usage examples.
00243 *
00244 *                       On return, *nsub will contain the number of axes in
00245 *                       the subimage; this may be zero if there were no axes
00246 *                       of the required type(s) (in which case no memory will
00247 *                       be allocated).  axes[] will contain the axis numbers
00248 *                       that were extracted.  The vector length must be
00249 *                       sufficient to contain all axis numbers.  No checks are
00250 *                       performed to verify that the coordinate axes are
00251 *                       consistent, this is done by wcsset().
00252 *
00253 *   wcsdst    struct wcsprm*
00254 *                       Struct describing the subimage.  wcsprm::flag should
00255 *                       be set to -1 if wcsdst was not previously initialized
00256 *                       (memory leaks may result if it was previously
00257 *                       initialized).
00258 *
00259 * Function return value:
00260 *             int       Status return value:
00261 *                         0: Success.
00262 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00263 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00264 *                        12: Invalid subimage specification.
00265 *                        13: Non-separable subimage coordinate system.
00266 *
00267 * Notes:
00268 *   Combinations of subimage axes of particular types may be extracted in the
00269 *   same order as they occur in the input image by combining preprocessor
00270 *   codes, for example
00271 *
00272 =     *nsub = 1;
00273 =     axes[0] = WCSSUB_LONGITUDE | WCSSUB_LATITUDE | WCSSUB_SPECTRAL;
00274 *
00275 *   would extract the longitude, latitude, and spectral axes in the same order
00276 *   as the input image.  If one of each were present, *nsub = 3 would be
00277 *   returned.
00278 *
00279 *   For convenience, WCSSUB_CELESTIAL is defined as the combination
00280 *   WCSSUB_LONGITUDE | WCSSUB_LATITUDE | WCSSUB_CUBEFACE.
00281 *
00282 *   The codes may also be negated to extract all but the types specified, for
00283 *   example
00284 *
00285 =     *nsub = 4;
00286 =     axes[0] = WCSSUB_LONGITUDE;
00287 =     axes[1] = WCSSUB_LATITUDE;
00288 =     axes[2] = WCSSUB_CUBEFACE;
00289 =     axes[3] = -(WCSSUB_SPECTRAL | WCSSUB_STOKES);
00290 *
00291 *   The last of these specifies all axis types other than spectral or Stokes.
00292 *   Extraction is done in the order specified by axes[] a longitude axis (if
00293 *   present) would be extracted first (via axes[0]) and not subsequently (via
00294 *   axes[3]).  Likewise for the latitude and cubeface axes in this example.
00295 *
00296 *   From the foregoing, it is apparent that the value of *nsub returned may be
00297 *   less than or greater than that given.  However, it will never exceed the
00298 *   number of axes in the input image.
00299 *
00300 *
00301 * wcscopy() macro - Copy routine for the wcsprm struct
00302 * ----------------------------------------------------
00303 * wcscopy() does a deep copy of one wcsprm struct to another.  As of
00304 * WCSLIB 3.6, it is implemented as a preprocessor macro that invokes
00305 * wcssub() with the nsub and axes pointers both set to zero.
00306 *
00307 *
00308 * wcsfree() - Destructor for the wcsprm struct
00309 * --------------------------------------------
00310 * wcsfree() frees memory allocated for the wcsprm arrays by wcsini() and/or
00311 * wcsset().  wcsini() records the memory it allocates and wcsfree() will only
00312 * attempt to free this.
00313 *
00314 * PLEASE NOTE: wcsfree() must not be invoked on a wcsprm struct that was not
00315 * initialized by wcsini().
00316 *
00317 * Returned:
00318 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00319 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00320 *
00321 * Function return value:
00322 *             int       Status return value:
00323 *                         0: Success.
00324 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00325 *
00326 *
00327 * wcsprt() - Print routine for the wcsprm struct
00328 * ----------------------------------------------
00329 * wcsprt() prints the contents of a wcsprm struct.
00330 *
00331 * Given:
00332 *   wcs       const struct wcsprm*
00333 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00334 *
00335 * Function return value:
00336 *             int       Status return value:
00337 *                         0: Success.
00338 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00339 *
00340 *
00341 * wcsset() - Setup routine for the wcsprm struct
00342 * ----------------------------------------------
00343 * wcsset() sets up a wcsprm struct according to information supplied within
00344 * it (refer to the description of the wcsprm struct).
00345 *
00346 * wcsset() recognizes the NCP projection and converts it to the equivalent SIN
00347 * projection and it also recognizes GLS as a synonym for SFL.  It also
00348 * translates the AIPS spectral types ('FREQ-LSR', 'FELO-HEL', etc.), possibly
00349 * changing the input header keywords wcsprm::ctype and/or wcsprm::specsys if
00350 * necessary.
00351 *
00352 * Note that this routine need not be called directly; it will be invoked by
00353 * wcsp2s() and wcss2p() if the wcsprm::flag is anything other than a
00354 * predefined magic value.
00355 *
00356 * Given and returned:
00357 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00358 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00359 *
00360 * Function return value:
00361 *             int       Status return value:
00362 *                         0: Success.
00363 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00364 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00365 *                         3: Linear transformation matrix is singular.
00366 *                         4: Inconsistent or unrecognized coordinate axis
00367 *                            types.
00368 *                         5: Invalid parameter value.
00369 *                         6: Invalid coordinate transformation parameters.
00370 *                         7: Ill-conditioned coordinate transformation
00371 *                            parameters.
00372 *
00373 *
00374 * wcsp2s() - Pixel-to-world transformation
00375 * ----------------------------------------
00376 * wcsp2s() transforms pixel coordinates to world coordinates.
00377 *
00378 * Given and returned:
00379 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00380 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00381 *
00382 * Given:
00383 *   ncoord,
00384 *   nelem     int       The number of coordinates, each of vector length
00385 *                       nelem but containing wcs.naxis coordinate elements.
00386 *                       Thus nelem must equal or exceed the value of the
00387 *                       NAXIS keyword unless ncoord == 1, in which case nelem
00388 *                       is not used.
00389 *   pixcrd    const double[ncoord][nelem]
00390 *                       Array of pixel coordinates.
00391 *
00392 * Returned:
00393 *   imgcrd    double[ncoord][nelem]
00394 *                       Array of intermediate world coordinates.  For
00395 *                       celestial axes, imgcrd[][wcs.lng] and
00396 *                       imgcrd[][wcs.lat] are the projected x-, and
00397 *                       y-coordinates in pseudo "degrees".  For spectral
00398 *                       axes, imgcrd[][wcs.spec] is the intermediate spectral
00399 *                       coordinate, in SI units.
00400 *
00401 *   phi,theta double[ncoord]
00402 *                       Longitude and latitude in the native coordinate system
00403 *                       of the projection [deg].
00404 *
00405 *   world     double[ncoord][nelem]
00406 *                       Array of world coordinates.  For celestial axes,
00407 *                       world[][wcs.lng] and world[][wcs.lat] are the
00408 *                       celestial longitude and latitude [deg].  For
00409 *                       spectral axes, imgcrd[][wcs.spec] is the intermediate
00410 *                       spectral coordinate, in SI units.
00411 *
00412 *   stat      int[ncoord]
00413 *                       Status return value for each coordinate:
00414 *                         0: Success.
00415 *                         1+: A bit mask indicating invalid pixel coordinate
00416 *                            element(s).
00417 *
00418 * Function return value:
00419 *             int       Status return value:
00420 *                         0: Success.
00421 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00422 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00423 *                         3: Linear transformation matrix is singular.
00424 *                         4: Inconsistent or unrecognized coordinate axis
00425 *                            types.
00426 *                         5: Invalid parameter value.
00427 *                         6: Invalid coordinate transformation parameters.
00428 *                         7: Ill-conditioned coordinate transformation
00429 *                            parameters.
00430 *                         8: One or more of the pixel coordinates were
00431 *                            invalid, as indicated by the stat vector.
00432 *
00433 *
00434 * wcss2p() - World-to-pixel transformation
00435 * ----------------------------------------
00436 * wcss2p() transforms world coordinates to pixel coordinates.
00437 *
00438 * Given and returned:
00439 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00440 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00441 *
00442 * Given:
00443 *   ncoord,
00444 *   nelem     int       The number of coordinates, each of vector length nelem
00445 *                       but containing wcs.naxis coordinate elements.  Thus
00446 *                       nelem must equal or exceed the value of the NAXIS
00447 *                       keyword unless ncoord == 1, in which case nelem is not
00448 *                       used.
00449 *   world     const double[ncoord][nelem]
00450 *                       Array of world coordinates.  For celestial axes,
00451 *                       world[][wcs.lng] and world[][wcs.lat] are the
00452 *                       celestial longitude and latitude [deg]. For spectral
00453 *                       axes, world[][wcs.spec] is the spectral coordinate, in
00454 *                       SI units.
00455 *
00456 * Returned:
00457 *   phi,theta double[ncoord]
00458 *                       Longitude and latitude in the native coordinate
00459 *                       system of the projection [deg].
00460 *
00461 *   imgcrd    double[ncoord][nelem]
00462 *                       Array of intermediate world coordinates.  For
00463 *                       celestial axes, imgcrd[][wcs.lng] and
00464 *                       imgcrd[][wcs.lat] are the projected x-, and
00465 *                       y-coordinates in pseudo "degrees".  For quadcube
00466 *                       projections with a CUBEFACE axis the face number is
00467 *                       also returned in imgcrd[][wcs.cubeface].  For
00468 *                       spectral axes, imgcrd[][wcs.spec] is the intermediate
00469 *                       spectral coordinate, in SI units.
00470 *
00471 *   pixcrd    double[ncoord][nelem]
00472 *                       Array of pixel coordinates.
00473 *
00474 *   stat      int[ncoord]
00475 *                       Status return value for each coordinate:
00476 *                         0: Success.
00477 *                         1+: A bit mask indicating invalid world coordinate
00478 *                            element(s).
00479 *
00480 * Function return value:
00481 *             int       Status return value:
00482 *                         0: Success.
00483 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00484 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00485 *                         3: Linear transformation matrix is singular.
00486 *                         4: Inconsistent or unrecognized coordinate axis
00487 *                            types.
00488 *                         5: Invalid parameter value.
00489 *                         6: Invalid coordinate transformation parameters.
00490 *                         7: Ill-conditioned coordinate transformation
00491 *                            parameters.
00492 *                         9: One or more of the world coordinates were
00493 *                            invalid, as indicated by the stat vector.
00494 *
00495 *
00496 * wcsmix() - Hybrid coordinate transformation
00497 * -------------------------------------------
00498 * wcsmix(), given either the celestial longitude or latitude plus an element
00499 * of the pixel coordinate, solves for the remaining elements by iterating on
00500 * the unknown celestial coordinate element using wcss2p().  Refer also to the
00501 * notes below.
00502 *
00503 * Given and returned:
00504 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00505 *                       Indices for the celestial coordinates obtained
00506 *                       by parsing the wcsprm::ctype[].
00507 *
00508 * Given:
00509 *   mixpix    int       Which element of the pixel coordinate is given.
00510 *   mixcel    int       Which element of the celestial coordinate is given:
00511 *                         1: Celestial longitude is given in
00512 *                            world[wcs.lng], latitude returned in
00513 *                            world[wcs.lat].
00514 *                         2: Celestial latitude is given in
00515 *                            world[wcs.lat], longitude returned in
00516 *                            world[wcs.lng].
00517 *
00518 *   vspan     const double[2]
00519 *                       Solution interval for the celestial coordinate [deg].
00520 *                       The ordering of the two limits is irrelevant.
00521 *                       Longitude ranges may be specified with any convenient
00522 *                       normalization, for example [-120,+120] is the same as
00523 *                       [240,480], except that the solution will be returned
00524 *                       with the same normalization, i.e. lie within the
00525 *                       interval specified.
00526 *
00527 *   vstep     const double
00528 *                       Step size for solution search [deg].  If zero, a
00529 *                       sensible, although perhaps non-optimal default will be
00530 *                       used.
00531 *
00532 *   viter     int       If a solution is not found then the step size will be
00533 *                       halved and the search recommenced.  viter controls how
00534 *                       many times the step size is halved.  The allowed range
00535 *                       is 5 - 10.
00536 *
00537 * Given and returned:
00538 *   world     double[naxis]
00539 *                       World coordinate elements.  world[wcs.lng] and
00540 *                       world[wcs.lat] are the celestial longitude and
00541 *                       latitude [deg].  Which is given and which returned
00542 *                       depends on the value of mixcel.  All other elements
00543 *                       are given.
00544 *
00545 * Returned:
00546 *   phi,theta double[naxis]
00547 *                       Longitude and latitude in the native coordinate
00548 *                       system of the projection [deg].
00549 *
00550 *   imgcrd    double[naxis]
00551 *                       Image coordinate elements.  imgcrd[wcs.lng] and
00552 *                       imgcrd[wcs.lat] are the projected x-, and
00553 *                       y-coordinates in pseudo "degrees".
00554 *
00555 * Given and returned:
00556 *   pixcrd    double[naxis]
00557 *                       Pixel coordinate.  The element indicated by mixpix is
00558 *                       given and the remaining elements are returned.
00559 *
00560 * Function return value:
00561 *             int       Status return value:
00562 *                         0: Success.
00563 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00564 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00565 *                         3: Linear transformation matrix is singular.
00566 *                         4: Inconsistent or unrecognized coordinate axis
00567 *                            types.
00568 *                         5: Invalid parameter value.
00569 *                         6: Invalid coordinate transformation parameters.
00570 *                         7: Ill-conditioned coordinate transformation
00571 *                            parameters.
00572 *                        10: Invalid world coordinate.
00573 *                        11: No solution found in the specified interval.
00574 *
00575 * Notes:
00576 *   Initially the specified solution interval is checked to see if it's a
00577 *   "crossing" interval.  If it isn't, a search is made for a crossing
00578 *   solution by iterating on the unknown celestial coordinate starting at the
00579 *   upper limit of the solution interval and decrementing by the specified
00580 *   step size.  A crossing is indicated if the trial value of the pixel
00581 *   coordinate steps through the value specified.  If a crossing interval is
00582 *   found then the solution is determined by a modified form of "regula falsi"
00583 *   division of the crossing interval.  If no crossing interval was found
00584 *   within the specified solution interval then a search is made for a
00585 *   "non-crossing" solution as may arise from a point of tangency.  The
00586 *   process is complicated by having to make allowance for the discontinuities
00587 *   that occur in all map projections.
00588 *
00589 *   Once one solution has been determined others may be found by subsequent
00590 *   invokations of wcsmix() with suitably restricted solution intervals.
00591 *
00592 *   Note the circumstance that arises when the solution point lies at a native
00593 *   pole of a projection in which the pole is represented as a finite curve,
00594 *   for example the zenithals and conics.  In such cases two or more valid
00595 *   solutions may exist but wcsmix() only ever returns one.
00596 *
00597 *   Because of its generality wcsmix() is very compute-intensive.  For
00598 *   compute-limited applications more efficient special-case solvers could be
00599 *   written for simple projections, for example non-oblique cylindrical
00600 *   projections.
00601 *
00602 *
00603 * wcssptr() - Spectral axis translation
00604 * -------------------------------------
00605 * wcssptr() translates the spectral axis in a wcsprm struct.  For example, a
00606 * 'FREQ' axis may be translated into 'ZOPT-F2W' and vice versa.
00607 *
00608 * Given and returned:
00609 *   wcs       struct wcsprm*
00610 *                       Coordinate transformation parameters.
00611 *   i         int*      Index of the spectral axis (0-relative).  If given < 0
00612 *                       it will be set to the first spectral axis identified
00613 *                       from the ctype[] keyvalues in the wcsprm struct.
00614 *   ctype     char[9]   Desired spectral CTYPEia.  Wildcarding may be used as
00615 *                       for the ctypeS2 argument to spctrn() as described in
00616 *                       the prologue of spc.h, i.e. if the final three
00617 *                       characters are specified as "???", or if just the
00618 *                       eighth character is specified as '?', the correct
00619 *                       algorithm code will be substituted and returned.
00620 *
00621 * Function return value:
00622 *             int       Status return value:
00623 *                         0: Success.
00624 *                         1: Null wcsprm pointer passed.
00625 *                         2: Memory allocation failed.
00626 *                         3: Linear transformation matrix is singular.
00627 *                         4: Inconsistent or unrecognized coordinate axis
00628 *                            types.
00629 *                         5: Invalid parameter value.
00630 *                         6: Invalid coordinate transformation parameters.
00631 *                         7: Ill-conditioned coordinate transformation
00632 *                            parameters.
00633 *                        12: Invalid subimage specification (no spectral
00634 *                            axis).
00635 *
00636 *
00637 * wcsprm struct - Coordinate transformation parameters
00638 * ----------------------------------------------------
00639 * The wcsprm struct contains information required to transform world
00640 * coordinates.  It consists of certain members that must be set by the user
00641 * ("given") and others that are set by the WCSLIB routines ("returned").
00642 * Some of the former are not actually required for transforming coordinates.
00643 * These are described as "auxiliary"; the struct simply provides a place to
00644 * store them, though they may be used by wcshdo() in constructing a FITS
00645 * header from a wcsprm struct.  Some of the returned values are supplied for
00646 * informational purposes and others are for internal use only as indicated.
00647 *
00648 * In practice, it is expected that a WCS parser would scan the FITS header to
00649 * determine the number of coordinate axes.  It would then use wcsini() to
00650 * allocate memory for arrays in the wcsprm struct and set default values.
00651 * Then as it reread the header and identified each WCS keyrecord it would load
00652 * the value into the relevant wcsprm array element.  This is essentially what
00653 * wcspih() does - refer to the prologue of wcshdr.h.  As the final step,
00654 * wcsset() is invoked, either directly or indirectly, to set the derived
00655 * members of the wcsprm struct.  wcsset() strips off trailing blanks in all
00656 * string members and null-fills the character array.
00657 *
00658 *   int flag
00659 *     (Given and returned) This flag must be set to zero whenever any of the
00660 *     following wcsprm struct members are set or changed:
00661 *
00662 *       - wcsprm::naxis (q.v., not normally set by the user),
00663 *       - wcsprm::crpix,
00664 *       - wcsprm::pc,
00665 *       - wcsprm::cdelt,
00666 *       - wcsprm::crval,
00667 *       - wcsprm::cunit,
00668 *       - wcsprm::ctype,
00669 *       - wcsprm::lonpole,
00670 *       - wcsprm::latpole,
00671 *       - wcsprm::restfrq,
00672 *       - wcsprm::restwav,
00673 *       - wcsprm::npv,
00674 *       - wcsprm::pv,
00675 *       - wcsprm::nps,
00676 *       - wcsprm::ps,
00677 *       - wcsprm::cd,
00678 *       - wcsprm::crota,
00679 *       - wcsprm::altlin.
00680 *
00681 *     This signals the initialization routine, wcsset(), to recompute the
00682 *     returned members of the celprm struct.  celset() will reset flag to
00683 *     indicate that this has been done.
00684 *
00685 *     PLEASE NOTE: flag should be set to -1 when wcsini() is called for the
00686 *     first time for a particular wcsprm struct in order to initialize memory
00687 *     management.  It must ONLY be used on the first initialization otherwise
00688 *     memory leaks may result.
00689 *
00690 *   int naxis
00691 *     (Given or returned) Number of pixel and world coordinate elements.
00692 *
00693 *     If wcsini() is used to initialize the linprm struct (as would normally
00694 *     be the case) then it will set naxis from the value passed to it as a
00695 *     function argument.  The user should not subsequently modify it.
00696 *
00697 *   double *crpix
00698 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of double containing
00699 *     the coordinate reference pixel, CRPIXja.
00700 *
00701 *   double *pc
00702 *     (Given) Address of the first element of the PCi_ja (pixel coordinate)
00703 *     transformation matrix.  The expected order is
00704 *
00705 =       struct wcsprm wcs;
00706 =       wcs.pc = {PC1_1, PC1_2, PC2_1, PC2_2};
00707 *
00708 *     This may be constructed conveniently from a 2-D array via
00709 *
00710 =       double m[2][2] = {{PC1_1, PC1_2},
00711 =                         {PC2_1, PC2_2}};
00712 *
00713 *     which is equivalent to
00714 *
00715 =       double m[2][2];
00716 =       m[0][0] = PC1_1;
00717 =       m[0][1] = PC1_2;
00718 =       m[1][0] = PC2_1;
00719 =       m[1][1] = PC2_2;
00720 *
00721 *     The storage order for this 2-D array is the same as for the 1-D array,
00722 *     whence
00723 *
00724 =       wcs.pc = *m;
00725 *
00726 *     would be legitimate.
00727 *
00728 *   double *cdelt
00729 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of double containing
00730 *     the coordinate increments, CDELTia.
00731 *
00732 *   double *crval
00733 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of double containing
00734 *     the coordinate reference values, CRVALia.
00735 *
00736 *   char (*cunit)[72]
00737 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of char[72] containing
00738 *     the CUNITia keyvalues which define the units of measurement of the
00739 *     CRVALia, CDELTia, and CDi_ja keywords.
00740 *
00741 *     As CUNITia is an optional header keyword, cunit[][72] may be left blank
00742 *     but otherwise is expected to contain a standard units specification as
00743 *     defined by WCS Paper I.  Utility function wcsutrn(), described in
00744 *     wcsunits.h, is available to translate commonly used non-standard units
00745 *     specifications but this must be done as a separate step before invoking
00746 *     wcsset().
00747 *
00748 *     For celestial axes, if cunit[][72] is not blank, wcsset() uses
00749 *     wcsunits() to parse it and scale cdelt[], crval[], and cd[][*] to
00750 *     degrees.  It then resets cunit[][72] to "deg".
00751 *
00752 *     For spectral axes, if cunit[][72] is not blank, wcsset() uses wcsunits()
00753 *     to parse it and scale cdelt[], crval[], and cd[][*] to SI units.  It
00754 *     then resets cunit[][72] accordingly.
00755 *
00756 *     wcsset() ignores cunit[][72] for other coordinate types; cunit[][72] may
00757 *     be used to label coordinate values.
00758 *
00759 *     These variables accomodate the longest allowed string-valued FITS
00760 *     keyword, being limited to 68 characters, plus the null-terminating
00761 *     character.
00762 *
00763 *   char (*ctype)[72]
00764 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of char[72] containing
00765 *     the coordinate axis types, CTYPEia.
00766 *
00767 *     The ctype[][72] keyword values must be in upper case and there must be
00768 *     zero or one pair of matched celestial axis types, and zero or one
00769 *     spectral axis.  The ctype[][72] strings should be padded with blanks on
00770 *     the right and null-terminated so that they are at least eight characters
00771 *     in length.
00772 *
00773 *     These variables accomodate the longest allowed string-valued FITS
00774 *     keyword, being limited to 68 characters, plus the null-terminating
00775 *     character.
00776 *
00777 *   double lonpole
00778 *     (Given and returned) The native longitude of the celestial pole, phi_p,
00779 *     given by LONPOLEa [deg] or by PVi_2a [deg] attached to the longitude
00780 *     axis which takes precedence if defined, and ...
00781 *   double latpole
00782 *     (Given and returned) ... the native latitude of the celestial pole,
00783 *     theta_p, given by LATPOLEa [deg] or by PVi_3a [deg] attached to the
00784 *     longitude axis which takes precedence if defined.
00785 *
00786 *     lonpole and latpole may be left to default to values set by wcsini()
00787 *     (see celprm::ref), but in any case they will be reset by wcsset() to
00788 *     the values actually used.  Note therefore that if the wcsprm struct is
00789 *     reused without resetting them, whether directly or via wcsini(), they
00790 *     will no longer have their default values.
00791 *
00792 *   double restfrq
00793 *     (Given) The rest frequency [Hz], and/or ...
00794 *   double restwav
00795 *     (Given) ... the rest wavelength in vacuuo [m], only one of which need be
00796 *     given, the other should be set to zero.
00797 *
00798 *   int npv
00799 *     (Given) The number of entries in the wcsprm::pv[] array.
00800 *
00801 *   int npvmax
00802 *     (Given or returned) The length of the wcsprm::pv[] array.
00803 *
00804 *     npvmax will be set by wcsini() if it allocates memory for wcsprm::pv[],
00805 *     otherwise it must be set by the user.  See also wcsnpv().
00806 *
00807 *   struct pvcard *pv
00808 *     (Given or returned) Address of the first element of an array of length
00809 *     npvmax of pvcard structs.  Set by wcsini() if it allocates memory for
00810 *     pv[], otherwise it must be set by the user.  See also wcsnpv().
00811 *
00812 *     As a FITS header parser encounters each PVi_ma keyword it should load it
00813 *     into a pvcard struct in the array and increment npv.  wcsset()
00814 *     interprets these as required.
00815 *
00816 *     Note that, if they were not given, wcsset() resets the entries for
00817 *     PVi_1a, PVi_2a, PVi_3a, and PVi_4a for longitude axis i to match
00818 *     (phi_0,theta_0), the native longitude and latitude of the reference
00819 *     point given by LONPOLEa and LATPOLEa.
00820 *
00821 *   int nps
00822 *     (Given) The number of entries in the wcsprm::ps[] array.
00823 *
00824 *   int npsmax
00825 *     (Given or returned) The length of the wcsprm::ps[] array.
00826 *
00827 *     npsmax will be set by wcsini() if it allocates memory for wcsprm::ps[],
00828 *     otherwise it must be set by the user.  See also wcsnps().
00829 *
00830 *   struct pscard *ps
00831 *     (Given or returned) Address of the first element of an array of length
00832 *     npsmax of pscard structs.  Set by wcsini() if it allocates memory for
00833 *     ps[], otherwise it must be set by the user.  See also wcsnps().
00834 *
00835 *     As a FITS header parser encounters each PSi_ma keyword it should load it
00836 *     into a pscard struct in the array and increment nps.  wcsset()
00837 *     interprets these as required (currently no PSi_ma keyvalues are
00838 *     recognized).
00839 *
00840 *   double *cd
00841 *     (Given) For historical compatibility, the wcsprm struct supports two
00842 *     alternate specifications of the linear transformation matrix, those
00843 *     associated with the CDi_ja keywords, and ...
00844 *   double *crota
00845 *     (Given) ... those associated with the CROTAia keywords.  Although these
00846 *     may not formally co-exist with PCi_ja, the approach taken here is simply
00847 *     to ignore them if given in conjunction with PCi_ja.
00848 *
00849 *   int altlin
00850 *     (Given) altlin is a bit flag that denotes which of the PCi_ja, CDi_ja
00851 *     and CROTAia keywords are present in the header:
00852 *
00853 *     - Bit 0: PCi_ja is present.
00854 *
00855 *     - Bit 1: CDi_ja is present.
00856 *
00857 *       Matrix elements in the IRAF convention are
00858 *       equivalent to the product CDi_ja = CDELTia * PCi_ja, but the
00859 *       defaults differ from that of the PCi_ja matrix.  If one or more
00860 *       CDi_ja keywords are present then all unspecified CDi_ja default to
00861 *       zero.  If no CDi_ja (or CROTAia) keywords are present, then the
00862 *       header is assumed to be in PCi_ja form whether or not any PCi_ja
00863 *       keywords are present since this results in an interpretation of
00864 *       CDELTia consistent with the original FITS specification.
00865 *
00866 *       While CDi_ja may not formally co-exist with PCi_ja, it may co-exist
00867 *       with CDELTia and CROTAia which are to be ignored.
00868 *
00869 *     - Bit 2: CROTAia is present.
00870 *
00871 *       In the AIPS convention, CROTAia may only be
00872 *       associated with the latitude axis of a celestial axis pair.  It
00873 *       specifies a rotation in the image plane that is applied AFTER the
00874 *       CDELTia; any other CROTAia keywords are ignored.
00875 *
00876 *       CROTAia may not formally co-exist with PCi_ja.
00877 *
00878 *       CROTAia and CDELTia may formally co-exist with CDi_ja but if so are to
00879 *       be ignored.
00880 *
00881 *     CDi_ja and CROTAia keywords, if found, are to be stored in the
00882 *     wcsprm::cd and wcsprm::crota arrays which are dimensioned similarly to
00883 *     wcsprm::pc and wcsprm::cdelt.  FITS
00884 *     header parsers should use the following procedure:
00885 *
00886 *     - Whenever a PCi_ja  keyword is encountered: altlin |= 1;
00887 *
00888 *     - Whenever a CDi_ja  keyword is encountered: altlin |= 2;
00889 *
00890 *     - Whenever a CROTAia keyword is encountered: altlin |= 4;
00891 *
00892 *     If none of these bits are set the PCi_ja representation results, i.e.
00893 *     wcsprm::pc and wcsprm::cdelt will be used as given.
00894 *
00895 *     These alternate specifications of the linear transformation matrix are
00896 *     translated immediately to PCi_ja by wcsset() and are invisible to the
00897 *     lower-level WCSLIB routines.  In particular, wcsset() resets
00898 *     wcsprm::cdelt to unity if CDi_ja is present (and no PCi_ja).
00899 *
00900 *     If CROTAia are present but none is associated with the latitude axis
00901 *     (and no PCi_ja or CDi_ja), then wcsset() reverts to a unity PCi_ja
00902 *     matrix.
00903 *
00904 *   int velref
00905 *     (Given) AIPS velocity code VELREF, refer to spcaips().
00906 *
00907 *   char alt[4]
00908 *     (Given, auxiliary) Character code for alternate coordinate descriptions
00909 *     (i.e. the 'a' in keyword names such as CTYPEia).  This is blank for the
00910 *     primary coordinate description, or one of the 26 upper-case letters,
00911 *     A-Z.
00912 *
00913 *     An array of four characters is provided for alignment purposes, only the
00914 *     first is used.
00915 *
00916 *   int colnum
00917 *     (Given, auxiliary) Where the coordinate representation is associated
00918 *     with an image-array column in a FITS binary table, this variable may be
00919 *     used to record the relevant column number.
00920 *
00921 *     It should be set to zero for an image header or pixel list.
00922 *
00923 *   int *colax
00924 *     (Given, auxiliary) Address of the first element of an array of int
00925 *     recording the column numbers for each axis in a pixel list.
00926 *
00927 *     The array elements should be set to zero for an image header or image
00928 *     array in a binary table.
00929 *
00930 *   char (*cname)[72]
00931 *     (Given, auxiliary) The address of the first element of an array of
00932 *     char[72] containing the coordinate axis names, CNAMEia.
00933 *
00934 *     These variables accomodate the longest allowed string-valued FITS
00935 *     keyword, being limited to 68 characters, plus the null-terminating
00936 *     character.
00937 *
00938 *   double *crder
00939 *     (Given, auxiliary) Address of the first element of an array of double
00940 *     recording the random error in the coordinate value, CRDERia.
00941 *   double *csyer
00942 *     (Given, auxiliary) Address of the first element of an array of double
00943 *     recording the systematic error in the coordinate value, CSYERia.
00944 *
00945 *   char dateavg[72]
00946 *     (Given, auxiliary) The date of a representative mid-point of the
00947 *     observation in ISO format, yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.
00948 *   char dateobs[72]
00949 *     (Given, auxiliary) The date of the start of the observation unless
00950 *     otherwise explained in the comment field of the DATE-OBS keyword, in
00951 *     ISO format, yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm:ss.
00952 *
00953 *   double equinox
00954 *     (Given, auxiliary) The equinox associated with dynamical equatorial or
00955 *     ecliptic coordinate systems, EQUINOXa (or EPOCH in older headers).  Not
00956 *     applicable to ICRS equatorial or ecliptic coordinates.
00957 *
00958 *   double mjdavg
00959 *     (Given, auxiliary) Modified Julian Date (MJD = JD - 2400000.5), MJD-AVG,
00960 *     corresponding to DATE-AVG.
00961 *   double mjdobs
00962 *     (Given, auxiliary) Modified Julian Date (MJD = JD - 2400000.5), MJD-OBS,
00963 *     corresponding to DATE-OBS.
00964 *
00965 *   double obsgeo[3]
00966 *     (Given, auxiliary) Location of the observer in a standard terrestrial
00967 *     reference frame, OBSGEO-X, OBSGEO-Y, OBSGEO-Z [m].
00968 *
00969 *   char radesys[72]
00970 *     (Given, auxiliary) The equatorial or ecliptic coordinate system type,
00971 *     RADESYSa.
00972 *
00973 *   char specsys[72]
00974 *     (Given, auxiliary) Spectral reference frame (standard of rest),
00975 *     SPECSYSa, and ...
00976 *   char ssysobs[72]
00977 *     (Given, auxiliary) ... the actual frame in which there is no
00978 *     differential variation in the spectral coordinate across the
00979 *     field-of-view, SSYSOBSa.
00980 *   double velosys
00981 *     (Given, auxiliary) The relative radial velocity [m/s] between the
00982 *     observer and the selected standard of rest in the direction of the
00983 *     celestial reference coordinate, VELOSYSa.
00984 *
00985 *   double zsource
00986 *     (Given, auxiliary) The redshift, ZSOURCEa, of the source, and ...
00987 *   char ssyssrc[72]
00988 *     (Given, auxiliary) ... the spectral reference frame (standard of rest)
00989 *     in which this was measured, SSYSSRCa.
00990 *
00991 *   double velangl
00992 *     (Given, auxiliary) The angle [deg] that should be used to decompose an
00993 *     observed velocity into radial and transverse components.
00994 *
00995 *   char wcsname[72]
00996 *     (Given, auxiliary) The name given to the coordinate representation,
00997 *     WCSNAMEa.  This variable accomodates the longest allowed string-valued
00998 *     FITS keyword, being limited to 68 characters, plus the null-terminating
00999 *     character.
01000 *
01001 *   int ntab
01002 *     (Given) See wcsprm::tab.
01003 *
01004 *   int nwtb
01005 *     (Given) See wcsprm::wtb.
01006 *
01007 *   struct tabprm *tab
01008 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of ntab tabprm structs
01009 *     for which memory has been allocated.  These are used to store tabular
01010 *     transformation parameters.
01011 *
01012 *     Although technically wcsprm::ntab and tab are "given", they will
01013 *     normally be set by invoking wcstab(), whether directly or indirectly.
01014 *
01015 *     The tabprm structs contain some members that must be supplied and others
01016 *     that are derived.  The information to be supplied comes primarily from
01017 *     arrays stored in one or more FITS binary table extensions.  These
01018 *     arrays, referred to here as "wcstab arrays", are themselves located by
01019 *     parameters stored in the FITS image header.
01020 *
01021 *   struct wtbarr *wtb
01022 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of nwtb wtbarr structs
01023 *     for which memory has been allocated.  These are used in extracting
01024 *     wcstab arrays from a FITS binary table.
01025 *
01026 *     Although technically wcsprm::nwtb and wtb are "given", they will
01027 *     normally be set by invoking wcstab(), whether directly or indirectly.
01028 *
01029 *   int *types
01030 *     (Returned) Address of the first element of an array of int containing a
01031 *     four-digit type code for each axis.
01032 *
01033 *     - First digit (i.e. 1000s):
01034 *       - 0: Non-specific coordinate type.
01035 *       - 1: Stokes coordinate.
01036 *       - 2: Celestial coordinate (including CUBEFACE).
01037 *       - 3: Spectral coordinate.
01038 *
01039 *     - Second digit (i.e. 100s):
01040 *       - 0: Linear axis.
01041 *       - 1: Quantized axis (STOKES, CUBEFACE).
01042 *       - 2: Non-linear celestial axis.
01043 *       - 3: Non-linear spectral axis.
01044 *       - 4: Logarithmic axis.
01045 *       - 5: Tabular axis.
01046 *
01047 *     - Third digit (i.e. 10s):
01048 *       - 0: Group number, e.g. lookup table number, being an index into the
01049 *            tabprm array (see above).
01050 *
01051 *     - The fourth digit is used as a qualifier depending on the axis type.
01052 *
01053 *       - For celestial axes:
01054 *         - 0: Longitude coordinate.
01055 *         - 1: Latitude coordinate.
01056 *         - 2: CUBEFACE number.
01057 *
01058 *       - For lookup tables: the axis number in a multidimensional table.
01059 *
01060 *     CTYPEia in "4-3" form with unrecognized algorithm code will have its
01061 *     type set to -1 and generate an error.
01062 *
01063 *   char lngtyp[8]
01064 *     (Returned) Four-character WCS celestial longitude and ...
01065 *   char lattyp[8]
01066 *     (Returned) ... latitude axis types. e.g. "RA", "DEC", "GLON", "GLAT",
01067 *     etc. extracted from 'RA--', 'DEC-', 'GLON', 'GLAT', etc. in the first
01068 *     four characters of CTYPEia but with trailing dashes removed.  (Declared
01069 *     as char[8] for alignment reasons.)
01070 *
01071 *   int lng
01072 *     (Returned) Index for the longitude coordinate, and ...
01073 *   int lat
01074 *     (Returned) ... index for the latitude coordinate, and ...
01075 *   int spec
01076 *     (Returned) ... index for the spectral coordinate in the imgcrd[][] and
01077 *     world[][] arrays in the API of wcsp2s(), wcss2p() and wcsmix().
01078 *
01079 *     These may also serve as indices into the pixcrd[][] array provided that
01080 *     the PCi_ja matrix does not transpose axes.
01081 *
01082 *   int cubeface
01083 *     (Returned) Index into the pixcrd[][] array for the CUBEFACE axis.  This
01084 *     is used for quadcube projections where the cube faces are stored on a
01085 *     separate axis (see wcs.h).
01086 *
01087 *   struct linprm lin
01088 *     (Returned) Linear transformation parameters (usage is described in the
01089 *     prologue to lin.h).
01090 *
01091 *   struct celprm cel
01092 *     (Returned) Celestial transformation parameters (usage is described in
01093 *     the prologue to cel.h).
01094 *
01095 *   struct spcprm spc
01096 *     (Returned) Spectral transformation parameters (usage is described in the
01097 *     prologue to spc.h).
01098 *
01099 *   int m_flag
01100 *     (For internal use only.)
01101 *   int m_naxis
01102 *     (For internal use only.)
01103 *   double *m_crpix
01104 *     (For internal use only.)
01105 *   double *m_pc
01106 *     (For internal use only.)
01107 *   double *m_cdelt
01108 *     (For internal use only.)
01109 *   double *m_crval
01110 *     (For internal use only.)
01111 *   char (*m_cunit)[72]
01112 *     (For internal use only.)
01113 *   char (*m_ctype)[72]
01114 *     (For internal use only.)
01115 *   struct pvcard *m_pv
01116 *     (For internal use only.)
01117 *   struct pscard *m_ps
01118 *     (For internal use only.)
01119 *   double *m_cd
01120 *     (For internal use only.)
01121 *   double *m_crota
01122 *     (For internal use only.)
01123 *   int *m_colax
01124 *     (For internal use only.)
01125 *   char (*m_cname)[72]
01126 *     (For internal use only.)
01127 *   double *m_crder
01128 *     (For internal use only.)
01129 *   double *m_csyer
01130 *     (For internal use only.)
01131 *   struct tabprm *m_tab
01132 *     (For internal use only.)
01133 *   struct wtbarr *m_wtb
01134 *     (For internal use only.)
01135 *
01136 *
01137 * pscard struct - Store for PSi_ma keyrecords
01138 * -------------------------------------------
01139 * The pscard struct is used to pass the parsed contents of PSi_ma keyrecords
01140 * to wcsset() via the wcsprm struct.
01141 *
01142 * All members of this struct are to be set by the user.
01143 *
01144 *   int i
01145 *     (Given) Axis number (1-relative), as in the FITS PSi_ma keyword.
01146 *
01147 *   int m
01148 *     (Given) Parameter number (non-negative), as in the FITS PSi_ma keyword.
01149 *
01150 *   char value[72]
01151 *     (Given) Parameter value.
01152 *
01153 *
01154 * pvcard struct - Store for PVi_ma keyrecords
01155 * -------------------------------------------
01156 * The pvcard struct is used to pass the parsed contents of PVi_ma keyrecords
01157 * to wcsset() via the wcsprm struct.
01158 *
01159 * All members of this struct are to be set by the user.
01160 *
01161 *   int i
01162 *     (Given) Axis number (1-relative), as in the FITS PVi_ma keyword.
01163 *
01164 *   int m
01165 *     (Given) Parameter number (non-negative), as in the FITS PVi_ma keyword.
01166 *
01167 *   double value
01168 *     (Given) Parameter value.
01169 *
01170 *
01171 * wtbarr struct - Extraction of coordinate lookup tables from BINTABLE
01172 * --------------------------------------------------------------------
01173 * Function wcstab(), which is invoked automatically by wcspih(), sets up an
01174 * array of wtbarr structs to assist in extracting coordinate lookup tables
01175 * from a binary table extension (BINTABLE) and copying them into the tabprm
01176 * structs stored in wcsprm.  Refer to the usage notes for wcspih() and
01177 * wcstab() in wcshdr.h, and also the prologue to tab.h.
01178 *
01179 * For C++ usage, because of a name space conflict with the wtbarr typedef
01180 * defined in CFITSIO header fitsio.h, the wtbarr struct is renamed to wtbarr_s
01181 * by preprocessor macro substitution with scope limited to wcs.h itself.
01182 *
01183 *   int i
01184 *     (Given) Image axis number.
01185 *
01186 *   int m
01187 *     (Given) wcstab array axis number for index vectors.
01188 *
01189 *   int kind
01190 *     (Given) Character identifying the wcstab array type:
01191 *       - c: coordinate array,
01192 *       - i: index vector.
01193 *
01194 *   char extnam[72]
01195 *     (Given) EXTNAME identifying the binary table extension.
01196 *
01197 *   int extver
01198 *     (Given) EXTVER identifying the binary table extension.
01199 *
01200 *   int extlev
01201 *     (Given) EXTLEV identifying the binary table extension.
01202 *
01203 *   char ttype[72]
01204 *     (Given) TTYPEn identifying the column of the binary table that contains
01205 *     the wcstab array.
01206 *
01207 *   long row
01208 *     (Given) Table row number.
01209 *
01210 *   int ndim
01211 *     (Given) Expected dimensionality of the wcstab array.
01212 *
01213 *   int *dimlen
01214 *     (Given) Address of the first element of an array of int of length ndim
01215 *     into which the wcstab array axis lengths are to be written.
01216 *
01217 *   double **arrayp
01218 *     (Given) Pointer to an array of double which is to be allocated by the
01219 *     user and into which the wcstab array is to be written.
01220 *
01221 *
01222 * Global variable: const char *wcs_errmsg[] - Status return messages
01223 * ------------------------------------------------------------------
01224 * Error messages to match the status value returned from each function.
01225 *
01226 *===========================================================================*/
01227

01240 #define WCSSUB_LONGITUDE 0x1001

01245 #define WCSSUB_STOKES    0x1010

01250 /* Struct used for storing PVi_ma keywords. */
01251 struct pvcard {
01252   int i;                        /* Axis number, as in PVi_ma (1-relative).  */
01253   int m;                        /* Parameter number, ditto  (0-relative).   */
01254   double value;                 /* Parameter value.                         */
01255 };
01256 
01257 /* Struct used for storing PSi_ma keywords. */
01258 struct pscard {
01259   int i;                        /* Axis number, as in PSi_ma (1-relative).  */
01260   int m;                        /* Parameter number, ditto  (0-relative).   */
01261   char value[72];               /* Parameter value.                         */
01262 };
01263 
01264                                 /* For extracting wcstab arrays.            */
01265 #ifdef __cplusplus
01266 #define wtbarr wtbarr_s         /* See prologue above.                      */
01267 #endif
01268 struct wtbarr {
01269   int  i;                       /* Image axis number.                       */
01270   int  m;                       /* Array axis number for index vectors.     */
01271   int  kind;                    /* wcstab array type.                       */
01272   char extnam[72];              /* EXTNAME of binary table extension.       */
01273   int  extver;                  /* EXTVER  of binary table extension.       */
01274   int  extlev;                  /* EXTLEV  of binary table extension.       */
01275   char ttype[72];               /* TTYPEn of column containing the array.   */
01276   long row;                     /* Table row number.                        */
01277   int  ndim;                    /* Expected wcstab array dimensionality.    */
01278   int  *dimlen;                 /* Where to write the array axis lengths.   */
01279   double **arrayp;              /* Where to write the address of the array  */
01280                                 /* allocated to store the wcstab array.     */
01281 };

01283 
01284 struct wcsprm {
01285   /* Initialization flag (see the prologue above).                          */
01286   /*------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
01287   int    flag;                  /* Set to zero to force initialization.     */
01288 
01289   /* FITS header keyvalues to be provided (see the prologue above).         */
01290   /*------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
01291   int    naxis;                 /* Number of axes (pixel and coordinate).   */
01292   double *crpix;                /* CRPIXja keyvalues for each pixel axis.   */
01293   double *pc;                   /* PCi_ja  linear transformation matrix.    */
01294   double *cdelt;                /* CDELTia keyvalues for each coord axis.   */
01295   double *crval;                /* CRVALia keyvalues for each coord axis.   */
01296 
01297   char   (*cunit)[72];          /* CUNITia keyvalues for each coord axis.   */
01298   char   (*ctype)[72];          /* CTYPEia keyvalues for each coord axis.   */
01299 
01300   double lonpole;               /* LONPOLEa keyvalue.                       */
01301   double latpole;               /* LATPOLEa keyvalue.                       */
01302 
01303   double restfrq;               /* RESTFRQa keyvalue.                       */
01304   double restwav;               /* RESTWAVa keyvalue.                       */
01305 
01306   int    npv;                   /* Number of PVi_ma keywords, and the       */
01307   int    npvmax;                /* number for which space was allocated.    */
01308   struct pvcard *pv;            /* PVi_ma keywords for each i and m.        */
01309 
01310   int    nps;                   /* Number of PSi_ma keywords, and the       */
01311   int    npsmax;                /* number for which space was allocated.    */
01312   struct pscard *ps;            /* PSi_ma keywords for each i and m.        */
01313 
01314   /* Alternative header keyvalues (see the prologue above).                 */
01315   /*------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
01316   double *cd;                   /* CDi_ja linear transformation matrix.     */
01317   double *crota;                /* CROTAia keyvalues for each coord axis.   */
01318   int    altlin;                /* Alternative representations              */
01319                                 /*   Bit 0: PCi_ja  is present,             */
01320                                 /*   Bit 1: CDi_ja  is present,             */
01321                                 /*   Bit 2: CROTAia is present.             */
01322   int    velref;                /* AIPS velocity code, VELREF.              */
01323 
01324   /* Auxiliary coordinate system information, not used by WCSLIB.           */
01325   char   alt[4];
01326   int    colnum;
01327   int    *colax;
01328 
01329   char   (*cname)[72];
01330   double *crder;
01331   double *csyer;
01332   char   dateavg[72];
01333   char   dateobs[72];
01334   double equinox;
01335   double mjdavg;
01336   double mjdobs;
01337   double obsgeo[3];
01338   char   radesys[72];
01339   char   specsys[72];
01340   char   ssysobs[72];
01341   double velosys;
01342   double zsource;
01343   char   ssyssrc[72];
01344   double velangl;
01345   char   wcsname[72];
01346 
01347   /* Coordinate lookup tables (see the prologue above).                     */
01348   /*------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
01349   int    ntab;                  /* Number of separate tables.               */
01350   int    nwtb;                  /* Number of wtbarr structs.                */
01351   struct tabprm *tab;           /* Tabular transformation parameters.       */
01352   struct wtbarr *wtb;           /* Array of wtbarr structs.                 */
01353 
01354   /* Information derived from the FITS header keyvalues by wcsset().        */
01355   /*------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
01356   int    *types;                /* Coordinate type codes for each axis.     */
01357   char   lngtyp[8], lattyp[8];  /* Celestial axis types, e.g. RA, DEC.      */
01358   int    lng, lat, spec;        /* Longitude, latitude and spectral axis    */
01359                                 /* indices (0-relative).                    */
01360   int    cubeface;              /* True if there is a CUBEFACE axis.        */
01361 
01362   struct linprm lin;            /* Linear    transformation parameters.     */
01363   struct celprm cel;            /* Celestial transformation parameters.     */
01364   struct spcprm spc;            /* Spectral  transformation parameters.     */
01365 
01366   int    m_flag, m_naxis;       /* The remainder are for memory management. */
01367   double *m_crpix, *m_pc, *m_cdelt, *m_crval;
01368   char  (*m_cunit)[72], (*m_ctype)[72];
01369   struct pvcard *m_pv;
01370   struct pscard *m_ps;
01371   double *m_cd, *m_crota;
01372   int    *m_colax;
01373   char  (*m_cname)[72];
01374   double *m_crder, *m_csyer;
01375   struct tabprm *m_tab;
01376   struct wtbarr *m_wtb;
01377 };
